title: Why did hospitals have these frogs in their supply rooms? - Carly Anne York

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary use of African clawed frogs in scientific research from the 1930s to the 1960s?

options.label: A
options.text: To study their camouflage ability

options.label: B
options.text: To develop new treatments for amphibian skin infections

options.label: C
options.text: To test for diseases in animals

options.label: D
options.text: To test for pregnancy in humans

multiple-choice.question: How do African clawed frogs capture their prey?

options.label: A
options.text: They use their long tongues to snatch up insects

options.label: B
options.text: They only use their powerful hind claws to tear apart larger animals

options.label: C
options.text: They suck food directly into their mouths, but do not use their hands

options.label: D
options.text: They use a combination of sucking food directly into their mouths and using their hands to catch larger prey

multiple-choice.question: What effect did removing the pituitary gland have on the African clawed frog's ability to camouflage?

options.label: A
options.text: It enhanced their ability to camouflage

options.label: B
options.text: It had no effect on their ability to camouflage

options.label: C
options.text: It impaired their ability to change color, but not to camouflage

options.label: D
options.text: It impaired their ability to camouflage

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of injecting African clawed frogs with a pituitary extract derived from an ox?

options.label: A
options.text: They began to lay eggs, but only in the presence of a male

options.label: B
options.text: They stopped laying eggs altogether

options.label: C
options.text: They did not respond to the injection

options.label: D
options.text: They began to lay eggs, even in the absence of a male

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the hormone found in the urine of pregnant people that is similar to the ox hormone?

options.label: A
options.text: Chorionic gonadotropin hormone (hCG)

options.label: B
options.text: Pituitary hormone

options.label: C
options.text: Human growth hormone

options.label: D
options.text: Estrogen

multiple-choice.question: What were the primary advantages of using African clawed frogs in pregnancy tests?

options.label: A
options.text: They were abundant in their native habitat

options.label: B
options.text: They had a long lifespan

options.label: C
options.text: They responded to hCG in roughly 9 hours

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What eventually replaced African clawed frogs in pregnancy testing?

options.label: A
options.text: Chemical tests that detected hCG directly

options.label: B
options.text: Other animal species

options.label: C
options.text: New technologies for studying amphibian biology

options.label: D
options.text: Computer simulations

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the fungus that can cause an infection in amphibians and disrupt their skin function?

options.label: A
options.text: Chytrid

options.label: B
options.text: Batrachochytrium

options.label: C
options.text: Fungal infection

options.label: D
options.text: Amphibian fungus

multiple-choice.question: Why are African clawed frogs now classified as an invasive species?

options.label: A
options.text: They have a deadly fungus that can infect other amphibians

options.label: B
options.text: They outcompete native amphibians for food and resources

options.label: C
options.text: They can escape from laboratory enclosures and establish wild populations

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the African clawed frog's role in scientific research?

options.label: A
options.text: They contributed to the development of new treatments for amphibian skin infections

options.label: B
options.text: They helped to understand the color-changing mechanism in amphibians

options.label: C
options.text: They were used in developmental biology studies

options.label: D
options.text: They were used in numerous studies, including developmental biology, space research, and pregnancy testing

title: Why is this black square famous? - Allison Leigh

multiple-choice.question: What was the title of Kazimir Malevich's radical artwork exhibited in St. Petersburg, Russia, on December 19th, 1915?

options.label: A
options.text: "Composition VIII"

options.label: B
options.text: "The Desert Landscape"

options.label: C
options.text: "Black Square"

options.label: D
options.text: "Black Circle"

multiple-choice.question: Where was Malevich's "Black Square" placed in the exhibition room, symbolically occupying a space traditionally reserved for religious icons?

options.label: A
options.text: The center of the room

options.label: B
options.text: The corner of the room

options.label: C
options.text: The wall opposite the entrance

options.label: D
options.text: Above the doorway

multiple-choice.question: What art movement did Malevich found, which emphasized the supremacy of feeling and non-objectivity?

options.label: A
options.text: Futurism

options.label: B
options.text: Impressionism

options.label: C
options.text: Cubism

options.label: D
options.text: Suprematism

multiple-choice.question: According to Malevich, what was the main characteristic of non-objectivity in art, which he believed was a departure from the world of objects?

options.label: A
options.text: Simplification of forms

options.label: B
options.text: Distortion of reality

options.label: C
options.text: Abstraction from everyday life

options.label: D
options.text: Complete non-representationalism

multiple-choice.question: What artistic style was enforced in the Soviet Union during Stalin's rule, which celebrated Soviet leaders and heroic workers?

options.label: A
options.text: Suprematism

options.label: B
options.text: Constructivism

options.label: C
options.text: Soviet Formalism

options.label: D
options.text: Socialist Realism

multiple-choice.question: In which region did Malevich live until he moved to Moscow in 1904?

options.label: A
options.text: St. Petersburg

options.label: B
options.text: Moscow

options.label: C
options.text: Ukraine

options.label: D
options.text: Poland

multiple-choice.question: What became the primary focus of Malevich's work after he realized that even avant-garde artists were still depicting everyday objects?

options.label: A
options.text: Form and structure

options.label: B
options.text: Objects and reality

options.label: C
options.text: Nature and landscape

options.label: D
options.text: Feeling and emotion

multiple-choice.question: How did Malevich respond to the criticism that the simplification and distortion of abstract art were ultimately meaningless?

options.label: A
options.text: He returned to figuration

options.label: B
options.text: He abandoned art altogether

options.label: C
options.text: He adopted a more realistic approach

options.label: D
options.text: He developed a new style called Suprematism

multiple-choice.question: What subtle details in Malevich's self-portrait hinted at his continued allegiance to his earlier ideas?

options.label: A
options.text: A vibrant red background

options.label: B
options.text: A quadrilateral formed by his open hand

options.label: C
options.text: A tiny black square in the corner

options.label: D
options.text: Both B and C

multiple-choice.question: What was the ultimate goal of Malevich's artistic endeavors, as reflected in his development of Suprematism?

options.label: A
options.text: To create a world of objects

options.label: B
options.text: To explore abstract concepts

options.label: C
options.text: To depict everyday life

options.label: D
options.text: To express pure feeling

title: What the fossil fuel industry doesn't want you to know - Al Gore

multiple-choice.question: What is the main issue with the current state of the climate crisis, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Greenhouse gas pollution is above the stratosphere.

options.label: B
options.text: Greenhouse gas pollution is below the troposphere, causing many second and third-order consequences.

options.label: C
options.text: The temperature is not rising as expected.

options.label: D
options.text: The ice is not melting as expected.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's opinion on the current progress in addressing the climate crisis?

options.label: A
options.text: Progress is sufficient to solve the crisis.

options.label: B
options.text: Progress is slow, and it's not enough to solve the crisis.

options.label: C
options.text: Progress is being made, but it needs to accelerate to solve the crisis.

options.label: D
options.text: Progress is too fast, and we need to slow it down.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the main obstacle to solving the climate crisis?

options.label: A
options.text: Lack of technology to capture emissions.

options.label: B
options.text: Lack of funding to invest in renewable energy.

options.label: C
options.text: Opposition from the fossil fuel industry.

options.label: D
options.text: Lack of international cooperation.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's opinion on the role of the fossil fuel industry in addressing the climate crisis?

options.label: A
options.text: They are working in good faith to find solutions.

options.label: B
options.text: They are not working in good faith and are actively fighting against solutions.

options.label: C
options.text: They are neutral and do not take a stance on the issue.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not relevant to the climate crisis.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the effectiveness of carbon capture and storage technology?

options.label: A
options.text: It is a viable solution to the climate crisis.

options.label: B
options.text: It is not a viable solution to the climate crisis due to its high cost and limited scalability.

options.label: C
options.text: It is a partial solution, but it's not enough.

options.label: D
options.text: It's a way to delay the transition to renewable energy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's opinion on the role of direct air capture technology in addressing the climate crisis?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a game-changer and will solve the climate crisis.

options.label: B
options.text: It's not a viable solution to the climate crisis due to its high energy requirements and cost.

options.label: C
options.text: It's a partial solution, but it's not enough.

options.label: D
options.text: It's a way to delay the transition to renewable energy.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the role of the financial system in addressing the climate crisis?

options.label: A
options.text: It's a major obstacle to solving the climate crisis due to its continued investment in fossil fuels.

options.label: B
options.text: It's not a major obstacle to solving the climate crisis.

options.label: C
options.text: It's a neutral factor that doesn't impact the climate crisis.

options.label: D
options.text: It's a way to fund the transition to renewable energy.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's opinion on the ability of the global community to address the climate crisis?

options.label: A
options.text: We are not capable of addressing the climate crisis.

options.label: B
options.text: We are capable of addressing the climate crisis, but it will take time.

options.label: C
options.text: We are capable of addressing the climate crisis, and we can speed it up with more effort.

options.label: D
options.text: We are capable of addressing the climate crisis, but it's not worth the effort.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the impact of true net-zero emissions on global temperatures?

options.label: A
options.text: It will not have any impact on global temperatures.

options.label: B
options.text: It will slow down the increase in global temperatures.

options.label: C
options.text: It will stop the increase in global temperatures with a lag time of as little as three to five years.

options.label: D
options.text: It will cause global temperatures to decrease.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's opinion on the ability of human beings to act to address the climate crisis?

options.label: A
options.text: We are not capable of acting to address the climate crisis.

options.label: B
options.text: We are capable of acting to address the climate crisis, but it will take time.

options.label: C
options.text: We are capable of acting to address the climate crisis, and we can speed it up with more effort.

options.label: D
options.text: We are capable of acting to address the climate crisis because the will to act is a renewable resource.

title: Can you change your sleep schedule?

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of the circadian system in the human body?

options.label: A
options.text: To regulate body temperature and metabolism

options.label: B
options.text: To manage the body's flow of hormones and coordinate organ functioning

options.label: C
options.text: To control the body's immune response and inflammation

options.label: D
options.text: To regulate the body's sleep-wake cycle only

options.text: Posterior hypothalamus

options.label: B
options.text: Anterior hypothalamus

options.label: C
options.text: Pineal gland

options.label: D
options.text: Suprachiasmatic nucleus

options.label: A
options.text: To increase alertness and energy

options.label: B
options.text: To regulate body temperature

options.label: C
options.text: To induce sleep and relaxation

options.label: D
options.text: To stimulate appetite and digestion

options.label: B
options.text: Sleep-wake cycle

options.label: C
options.text: Body clock

options.label: D
options.text: Biological clock

options.label: A
options.text: Melatonin

options.label: B
options.text: Cortisol

options.label: C
options.text: Insulin

options.label: D
options.text: Adrenaline

options.label: A
options.text: Light hygiene

options.label: B
options.text: Sleep hygiene

options.label: C
options.text: Circadian entrainment

options.label: D
options.text: Morning sunlight therapy

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential consequence of having a compromised circadian rhythm?

options.label: A
options.text: Improved sleep quality and increased energy

options.label: B
options.text: Enhanced immune function and reduced inflammation

options.label: C
options.text: Metabolic disorders and a vulnerable immune system

options.label: D
options.text: Increased productivity and better time management

options.label: A
options.text: Sleep hygiene

options.label: B
options.text: Circadian entrainment

options.label: C
options.text: Sleep discipline

options.label: D
options.text: Consistent sleeping habits

multiple-choice.question: What factor plays a significant role in determining an individual's preferred sleep schedule?

options.label: A
options.text: Age and lifestyle

options.label: B
options.text: Genetics and environment

options.label: C
options.text: Hormonal balance and diet

options.label: D
options.text: Hormonal quirks and individual differences in the circadian system

multiple-choice.question: What is the key takeaway from the text regarding sleep schedules?

options.label: A
options.text: Everyone should follow a strict sleep schedule to maintain optimal health.

options.label: B
options.text: Sleep schedules are predetermined at birth and cannot be changed.

options.label: C
options.text: As long as you're consistent, there's no wrong time to wake up or go to sleep.

options.label: D

title: Does COVID mess with your DNA?

multiple-choice.question: What is long COVID informally defined as?

options.label: A
options.text: A condition that occurs immediately after infection with the SARS-CoV-2 virus

options.label: B
options.text: A condition characterized by persistent symptoms of illness between 4 weeks and 3 months following infection with the SARS-CoV-2 virus

options.label: C
options.text: A condition that occurs only in people with a weakened immune system

options.label: D
options.text: A condition that occurs only in people with severe COVID-19 symptoms

multiple-choice.question: What is epigenetics?

options.label: A
options.text: The study of the sequence of DNA in an organism's nucleus

options.label: B
options.text: The study of how cells decide which genes to use when

options.label: C
options.text: The study of how the cell's machinery uses genetic information

options.label: D
options.text: The study of how the cell's machinery modulates genetic information without changing the sequence of DNA

multiple-choice.question: What is DNA methylation?

options.label: A
options.text: A type of epigenetic modification that adds a tag to quiet the gene down

options.label: B
options.text: A type of epigenetic modification that adds a tag to increase the gene's expression

options.label: C
options.text: A type of epigenetic modification that has no effect on gene expression

options.label: D
options.text: A type of epigenetic modification that changes the sequence of DNA

multiple-choice.question: What is believed to happen to epigenetic signals in the body during a SARS-CoV-2 infection?

options.label: A
options.text: The virus directly changes the epigenetic signals

options.label: B
options.text: The virus has no effect on epigenetic signals

options.label: C
options.text: The body produces more or less of the products of certain genes to make infection less severe

options.label: D
options.text: The epigenetic signals are completely reset

multiple-choice.question: What did the Swedish research group find in terms of DNA methylation in patients with long COVID?

options.label: A
options.text: No changes in DNA methylation

options.label: B
options.text: Changes in DNA methylation in genes related to inflammation and response to infection

options.label: C
options.text: Changes in DNA methylation in genes related to ACE2, histamine signaling, and taste and smell

options.label: D
options.text: Changes in DNA methylation in genes related to cardiovascular disease

multiple-choice.question: What did the US-based research group find in terms of DNA methylation in patients with long COVID?

options.label: A
options.text: Changes in DNA methylation in genes related to inflammation and response to infection

options.label: B
options.text: Changes in DNA methylation in genes related to ACE2 and histamine signaling

options.label: C
options.text: Changes in DNA methylation in genes related to taste and smell

options.label: D
options.text: No changes in DNA methylation

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the potential benefits of understanding the link between long COVID and chronic fatigue syndrome?

options.label: A
options.text: Developing new treatments for long COVID

options.label: B
options.text: Developing new treatments for chronic fatigue syndrome

options.label: C
options.text: Understanding two diseases instead of one

options.label: D
options.text: Understanding the cause of long COVID

multiple-choice.question: What did the Swedish research group notice in terms of self-antibodies in patients with long COVID?

options.label: A
options.text: No self-antibodies

options.label: B
options.text: Self-antibodies similar to those found in patients with MECFS

options.label: C
options.text: Self-antibodies related to ACE2 only

options.label: D
options.text: Self-antibodies related to histamine signaling only

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the potential explanations for the increase in cardiovascular events following COVID-19 infection?

options.label: A
options.text: The SARS-CoV-2 virus directly causes cardiovascular disease

options.label: B
options.text: The pattern of gene expression changes in response to COVID-19 infection may contribute to an increased risk of cardiovascular events

options.label: C
options.text: The SARS-CoV-2 virus has no effect on cardiovascular disease

options.label: D
options.text: The SARS-CoV-2 virus is not related to cardiovascular disease

options.label: A
options.text: To provide financial support for the production of SciShow videos

options.label: B
options.text: To provide access to exclusive content and perks

options.label: C
options.text: To participate in the creation of SciShow videos

options.label: D

title: The one thing stopping jellyfish from taking over - Mariela Pajuelo & Javier Antonio Quinones

multiple-choice.question: What is currently happening to jellyfish populations in the world's oceans?

options.label: A
options.text: They are declining due to overfishing.

options.label: B
options.text: They are rapidly increasing and overwhelming the oceans.

options.label: C
options.text: They are remaining stable due to natural balance.

options.label: D
options.text: They are disappearing due to climate change.

multiple-choice.question: Which marine animal is among the most ancient predators of jellyfish?

options.label: A
options.text: Sharks

options.label: B
options.text: Dolphins

options.label: C
options.text: Sea turtles

options.label: D
options.text: Whales

options.label: A
options.text: It consists mainly of fish eggs and larvae.

options.label: B
options.text: It consists almost exclusively of jellyfish.

options.label: C
options.text: It consists mainly of crustaceans.

options.label: D
options.text: It consists mainly of plankton.

multiple-choice.question: Why are jellyfish venomous harpoons (nematocysts) ineffective against sea turtles?

options.label: A
options.text: Because sea turtles have a thick layer of fat that protects them.

options.label: B
options.text: Because sea turtles have thick scales covered in keratin that protect their skin.

options.label: C
options.text: Because sea turtles are too big to be affected by jellyfish stings.

options.label: D
options.text: Because jellyfish stings are not potent enough to harm sea turtles.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary defense mechanism of jellyfish populations?

options.label: A
options.text: Their ability to reproduce sexually.

options.label: B
options.text: Their ability to reproduce asexually.

options.label: C
options.text: Their ability to release venomous harpoons (nematocysts).

options.label: D
options.text: Their ability to reproduce quickly and frequently, both sexually and asexually.

multiple-choice.question: What factors are contributing to the increased frequency of jellyfish blooms?

options.label: A
options.text: Climate change, fertilizer runoff from farms, marine construction, and pollution.

options.label: B
options.text: Climate change and fertilizer runoff from farms.

options.label: C
options.text: Fertilizer runoff from farms and pollution.

options.label: D
options.text: Pollution and marine construction.

multiple-choice.question: What is a crucial step in preventing jellyfish populations from getting out of hand?

options.label: A
options.text: Protecting their natural predators, such as sea turtles.

options.label: B
options.text: Reducing fertilizer runoff from farms.

options.label: C
options.text: Reducing pollution in the oceans.

options.label: D
options.text: Implementing policy-based solutions alone.

multiple-choice.question: What is a solution to minimize the impact of small-scale fisheries on sea turtles?

options.label: A
options.text: Attaching green LED lights to gillnets.

options.label: B
options.text: Using nets that are designed to catch only fish.

options.label: C
options.text: Implementing catch limits for sea turtles.

options.label: D
options.text: Reducing the number of fishing nets used.

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential consequence of the current practices of small-scale fisheries in the Eastern Pacific?

options.label: A
options.text: The leatherback sea turtle population is increasing.

options.label: B
options.text: The leatherback sea turtle population is stable.

options.label: C
options.text: The leatherback sea turtle population is decreasing.

options.label: D
options.text: The leatherback sea turtle population is at risk of extinction in the next 60 years.

multiple-choice.question: What is a benefit of using green LED lights on gillnets?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases the catch of fish.

options.label: B
options.text: It reduces the catch of fish.

options.label: C
options.text: It allows sea turtles, dolphins, and seabirds to avoid fishing gear.

options.label: D
options.text: It reduces the cost of fishing gear.

options.text: Meditation

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: Higher levels of positive emotions, creativity, and feelings of accomplishment

options.label: C
options.text: Enhanced stress and reduced learning

options.label: D
options.text: Increased anxiety and decreased productivity

options.text: Feeling easily distracted and having difficulty concentrating

options.label: B
options.text: Feeling effortlessly engaged in a task and having difficulty stopping

options.label: C
options.text: Feeling bored and uninterested in the activity

options.label: D
options.text: Feeling anxious and self-judgmental

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: Why did Megalodon go extinct? - Jack Cooper and Catalina Pimiento

multiple-choice.question: In 1667, what did a Danish scientist conclude about the mysterious stones previously believed to have medicinal powers?

options.label: A
options.text: They were serpent tongues from ancient species.

options.label: B
options.text: They were fossilized teeth of a prehistoric shark species.

options.label: C
options.text: They were rocks that fell from the sky during lunar eclipses.

options.label: D
options.text: They were a type of gemstone with healing properties.

multiple-choice.question: What was unique about the composition of megalodon skeletons compared to other animals?

options.label: A
options.text: They were made entirely of bone, like mammals.

options.label: B
options.text: They were made of a combination of cartilage and bone, like some fish.

options.label: C
options.text: They were primarily made of cartilaginous material, like most sharks.

options.label: D
options.text: They were absent, leaving behind only teeth and vertebrae.

multiple-choice.question: According to researchers, what was the estimated volume of a megalodon's stomach, which allowed it to consume large prey in a few bites?

options.label: A
options.text: 1,000 liters, similar to that of a large fish.

options.label: B
options.text: 5,000 liters, comparable to that of a small whale.

options.label: C
options.text: 10,000 liters, big enough to fit an entire orca.

options.label: D
options.text: 20,000 liters, the largest of any known animal.

multiple-choice.question: What were some contributing factors to the extinction of megalodons around 3.5 million years ago?

options.label: A
options.text: Global climate change and the loss of coastal habitats.

options.label: B
options.text: Overhunting by early human populations.

options.label: C
options.text: Increased competition with other predators, such as great white sharks.

options.label: D
options.text: Both A and C, a combination of climate change and competition.

multiple-choice.question: How many vertebrae are preserved in the exceptionally well-preserved spinal column of a 46-year-old megalodon?

options.label: A
options.text: 50 vertebrae, a relatively short spinal column.

options.label: B
options.text: 100 vertebrae, a moderate-sized spinal column.

options.label: C
options.text: 141 vertebrae, an exceptionally well-preserved spinal column.

options.label: D
options.text: 200 vertebrae, the longest spinal column of any known shark.

multiple-choice.question: What mechanism allowed megalodons to navigate cold waters and attack prey with bursts of speed, but also imposed high energetic demands?

options.label: A
options.text: Their massive size and powerful jaws.

options.label: B
options.text: Their ability to regulate their body temperature.

options.label: C
options.text: Their speed and agility in the water.

options.label: D
options.text: Their streamlined bodies, reducing drag and increasing efficiency.

multiple-choice.question: What was the effect of megalodons' extinction on the ecosystem, considering their role as apex predators?

options.label: A
options.text: The ecosystem remained unchanged, with no significant impacts.

options.label: B
options.text: The ecosystem became more stable, with fewer predators competing for resources.

options.label: C
options.text: The ecosystem became less diverse, with many species going extinct.

options.label: D
options.text: The ecosystem destabilized, with many species affected by the loss of a key predator.

multiple-choice.question: What was the relationship between megalodons and other predators, including the great white shark?

options.label: A
options.text: They were direct competitors, competing for the same resources.

options.label: B
options.text: They were prey, with other predators feeding on them.

options.label: C
options.text: They were symbiotic, working together to hunt and feed.

options.label: D
options.text: They were apex predators with some competition from other sharks.

multiple-choice.question: Based on the similarities with great white shark teeth, what was the estimated length of megalodons?

options.label: A
options.text: 10 meters, similar to that of a large whale.

options.label: B
options.text: 15 meters, comparable to that of a small island.

options.label: C
options.text: 20 meters, three times longer than great white sharks.

options.label: D
options.text: 25 meters, the longest of any known shark species.

multiple-choice.question: What does the megalodon's extinction illustrate in the context of ecological interdependence?

options.label: A
options.text: Apex predators are unnecessary for the ecosystem, and their loss has no significant impacts.

options.label: B
options.text: The loss of a single species can have significant consequences for the ecosystem.

options.label: C
options.text: The ecosystem is resilient to changes, and the loss of one species has little impact.

options.label: D
options.text: The megalodon was an isolated species, with no significant connections to other species.

title: 1816: The year with no summer - David Biello

options.label: B
options.text: Mount Krakatoa

options.label: C
options.text: Mount Tambora

options.label: D
options.text: Mount Vesuvius

options.label: A
options.text: It increased the amount of sunlight reaching the Earth

options.label: B
options.text: It caused a localized cooling effect

options.label: C
options.text: It had a minimal effect on the climate

options.label: D
options.text: It blocked out the sun for almost an entire year, leading to a global cooling effect

options.text: It led to a global economic boom

options.label: B
options.text: It had a minimal effect on the environment

options.label: C
options.text: It led to a global drought

options.label: D
options.text: It caused widespread famines and disrupted agriculture

multiple-choice.question: What term describes the class of deliberate, large-scale interventions in Earth's natural systems intended to help restrain climate change?

options.label: B
options.text: Environmental engineering

options.label: C
options.text: Atmospheric engineering

options.label: D
options.text: Geoengineering

options.label: B
options.text: Solar energy management

options.label: C
options.text: Ocean fertilization

options.label: D
options.text: Solar radiation management

options.label: B
options.text: To increase the amount of sunlight reaching the Earth

options.label: C
options.text: To cause a solar eclipse

options.label: D
options.text: To slow the effects of global warming by reducing the amount of sunlight that reaches the Earth

options.text: The Krakatoa eruption

options.label: B
options.text: The Pinatubo eruption

options.label: C
options.text: The Tambora eruption

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential risk associated with cooling temperatures caused by geoengineering schemes?

options.label: B
options.text: It may have a minimal effect on the environment

options.label: C
options.text: It may lead to predictable environmental outcomes

options.label: D
options.text: It may lead to unpredictable and potentially severe environmental consequences, such as changes in precipitation patterns and extreme weather events

multiple-choice.question: Why are some scientists running small-scale experiments to enhance marine clouds?

options.label: A
options.text: To slow the effects of global warming globally

options.label: B
options.text: To replicate the environmental effects of the eruption of Mount Tambora

options.label: C
options.text: To cause a solar eclipse

options.label: D
options.text: To protect specific ecosystems, such as the Great Barrier Reef, from further heating and bleaching

multiple-choice.question: Why are scientists investigating the impacts of geoengineering?

options.label: A
options.text: To replicate the environmental effects of the eruption of Mount Tambora

options.label: B
options.text: To slow the effects of global warming

options.label: C
options.text: To prepare for the possibility of rogue actors using geoengineering without governmental approval

options.text: To understand the potential impacts on the environment, develop a last resort to address climate change, prepare for potential unauthorized use, and inform strategies for mitigating climate change
